dialogues.text: If you’re gonna do something... She rolls her eyes and pads down the hall with the glass wine still in her hand.  23.

dialogues.text: And easy on El Vino from now on...

dialogues.text: Shit! She stamps on the brakes. Her bag slides forward on the s teetering on the edge. Eva reaches for it and grabs it be it falls, breathing a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Are you okay?... Eva... this should be good news...

dialogues.text: Hands straightening up the dishes on a beautifully laid o table until it looks perfect...but looking closer the han are shaking... PULL OUT;  24. dialogues.text: You’re pregnant. Eva turns and flushes. She can’t conceal her disappointme at having lost her big moment. She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Looks that way.

dialogues.speaker: LATER -
dialogues.text: Eva picks up a waiting champagne bottle from it’s ice buc and goes to fill Franklin’s glass but he covers it with h hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Hey, c’mon, we’re in this together. He grins and picks up the cranberry juice, pouring himsel healthy glass, holding it up for a toast.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: La chaim! They clink glasses and Eva takes a swig, barely managing disguise a grimace at the disappointingly sickly sweet ta of the juice.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Welcome to your new life! Eva grins, but as Franklin digs into his meal she looks w a little regret at the discarded champagne bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S. Franklin whistling cheerfully from the bathroom.  25. Eva pulls off her white dress and looks at her flat stoma in the mirror running her hand over it ruefully. TIME JUMP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands rifling through the wardrobe rail flicking passed endless hangers, rejecting them all. Eventually a smart rain coat is pulled out. Eva stands in front of the mirror with the coat on. From the front it looks OK but when she turns to the side looks ridiculous, she can’t even belt it. She casts it as on the bed.

dialogues.text: Close in. High heel shoes clacking in front of Eva, The back of a WOMAN wearing a trench coat like the one Ev couldn't fit. All male heads turn as she passes. EXT COFFEE VENDOR - DAY.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Double espresso please. The woman at the counter looks at Eva’s growing bump and raises her eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: You sure?...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Yes I’m sure. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE EVA’S APARTMENT - DAY. Eva struggling with too many grocery bags whilst trying t fish in her purse for her keys. dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Hey come and check it out, I got some cool stuff... Eva follows him looking a little forlorn.

dialogues.speaker: CLASS TUTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And one, two, three. And breathe. Mothers sit cross legged on the floor, eyes closed with t partners hugging them from behind. Eva and Franklin are amongst them, Eva is the only one wi her eyes open. Snorts of released air, resound around her.

dialogues.speaker: CLASS TUTOR
dialogues.text: (her face raised to the heavens) Feel the baby deep inside...Feel the deep maternal bond. The miraculous and transcendental bond. And breathe. dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (whispered) Hey, shhhh, c’mon.

dialogues.speaker: CLASS TUTOR
dialogues.text: And relax...OK Guys, that’s it for now... (she smiles benevolently) See you all next week. The pregnant woman and their partners open their eyes, th all start to clap.  27. Eva stares around at the others blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pick up pulls up at the lights.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey what do you think about Selim? Franklin frowns at her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You’ve got to be kidding. Selim Plaskett!?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No... Selim Khachadourian has more of a ring.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Yeah it has the ring of a kid that’s not related to me.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Funny that’s exactly how Peter Plaskett sounds to me. The light changes and they pull away. EXT. STREET - EARLY EVENING. Franklin's pick up pulls up and they both get out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: ...my parents would have a cow.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I just don’t see why I should get varicose veins for a Plaskett...It’s a gross name.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: So that’s why you didn’t take it when we got married. You hate my name!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I don’t hate it...it’s just so...American. I mean...  28.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: OK tell you what if it’s a boy ‘Plaskett’, if it’s a girl you can have ‘Khachadourian’.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So a girl doesn’t matter to you... He raises his hands and interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: OK ok, if it’s a girl Plaskett. But on one condition, none of this Selim Souvlaki stuff for the first name. Something AMERICAN. Deal? Eva laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: OK deal. INT. BEDROOM - MORNING; SOME MONTHS LATER. Eva in bed Alone. Swollen; sweating. A print of Degas’s backstage dancers. Eva stares at the girls, who seem to somehow be mocking her in return. Eva closes her eyes, praying for the sickening moment to pass. Franklin enters the darkened room and sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Promise me you won’t go to work today. Eva is about to protest.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (firmly) Promise. Eva nods imperceptibly. Franklin kisses her on the forehe then rises and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Why don’t you fix up the nursery if you're bored. You’ve hardly looked at it.  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva wanders around aimlessly, enjoying the late afternoon sunshine. She looks a lot fresher but clearly at a loose She passes a shelf stacked with records and flicks throug them, slides out a Billy Joel album, smiles at the cheesy cover and returns it to the shelf. She rubs her bulging belly.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey Kid...Lets hope you have better taste in music than the old man huh? She flicks to the back of the stack, her old ‘single life records.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Aha! She pulls out, Talking heads; ‘Speaking in Tongues’. dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You’d better not give me stretch marks...you little bastard. She holds her big belly in her hands and steps awkwardly the couch, jumping up and down in time to the music. SCRREECH. The music stops, the needle dragged off the rec

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey! She turns mid leap to see Franklin glowering at her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing, trying to have a miscarriage?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Having a good time for once, is that illegal?  30. She plonks herself down on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Awww...Stop feeling sorry for yourself and grow up...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What’s the matter Franklin? Am I not playing mommies and daddies right? Christ, if I’d known that’s what you were expecting I wouldn’t have bothered. Franklin’s face turns beet red.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (quietly furious) It’s too late for second thoughts now Eva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S. The sound of running water. Eva appears from the bathroom, passes the door of the new nursery, hesitates, then pushes it open. The room is full of boxes, the crib set up in the middle the floor, caught in the glow of the street lights. She pulls the baby blanket from the crib, draping it roun her shoulder and twists the mobile hanging above it. She sits on one of the boxes, the simplistic chimes of ‘Twinkle, twinkle little star’ play round endlessly. CUT TO BLACK. O.S. Animalistic, unearthly moans.

dialogues.speaker: DR RHIENSTEIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Eva, you’re resisting.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (a furious screech) It’s killing me...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Lights? a light, a singular, blinding light.  31. Tight on Franklin’s big hand held in Eva's vice like grip till it’s painful, white knuckled, about to be mashed to pulp and then it’s.... suddenly released. dialogues.text: Don’t worry...they don’t always take to it first time...

dialogues.text: Hey, sorry I’m late just got called in on another job. Seems I’m more popular than ever...

dialogues.text: FRANKLIN (cont'd) This whole city’s anti-child...I’m only just beginning to notice. Kevin rouses and quietly takes the bottle offered by Franklin.

dialogues.text: See? He seems pretty good natured to me...

dialogues.text: Touch warm. Go get some rest I’‘1l fix dinner. She shuffles back to the couch, looking a little crest fa at Franklin’s lack of attention.

dialogues.text: Oh her... didn’t work out.

dialogues.speaker: SIOBHAN
dialogues.text: (unwrapping the scarf and shouting over the wailing) Oh my god, Eva, it’s beautiful... you really shouldn't have.

dialogues.text: (turning to Eva) What about you, can you remember it, that moment? Joining the conversation with a jolt, she was miles away.

dialogues.text: (shrugging, searching for words ) Yeah you’re right...indescribable..

dialogues.text: How about you Eva? I guess the littlest hobo is grounded for a while huh?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Actually I was talking to marketing last week, they’re proposing a new guide... AFRIWAP, thought it had a ring... Franklin doesn’t say anything but his eyes show a combina of surprise and annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Of course it wouldn’t happen for a while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva slides the elevator gate open and steps into the loft it’s a bomb site, toys strewn everywhere, baby food splattered on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Siobhan? O.S. Muted cries from the other room, but not Kevin's. Eva follows the sound, bending to pick up Siobhan’s Chine scarf from the floor, it’s torn to shreds.  43. Eva enters the bedroom, Siobhan leans over Kevin (almost and a half now) on the changing table her hair tangled an caught in Kevin’s vice-like grip. She slowly manages to extricate herself.

dialogues.speaker: SIOBHAN
dialogues.text: (wiping away a tear) I’m sure he’s old enough to know how much that hurts. Eva grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (placating) Let me make you a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siobhan emerges from the bathroom. She’s straightened her up but still looks like shit. Much thinner than she was before and with dark circles under her eyes. She sits down at the table and stirs her coffee. O.S. next door Kevin has found a rattle and his xylophone begins a hideous discordant clanking.

dialogues.speaker: SIOBHAN
dialogues.text: Thanks... oh by the way, we’re almost out of baby food.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: SIOBHAN
dialogues.text: (almost tearful) It doesn’t all go in his mouth you know! A uncomfortable silence. O.S. The xylophoning stops replaced by a high pitched wai Eva and Siobhan look at each other but neither makes a mo from the table.

dialogues.speaker: SIOBHAN
dialogues.text: (opening the floodgates) Eva, I’m knackered... Eva sags, she knows what’s coming next.

dialogues.speaker: SIOBHAN
dialogues.text: -..-I mean you’ll need someone else when you move to the burbs anyway. Eva’s thrown for a moment, the burbs?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (a little desperately) Would you like more money?

dialogues.speaker: SIOBHAN
dialogues.text: The pays great Eva... I just can’t do it anymore... every morning I wake up... INT. VIEW FROM THE WINDOW, TRIBECA LOFT - A MOMENT LATER. Eva watches as Siobhan exits the apartment block frowning biting her nails, She hurries down the street, until she’ almost running. O.S. Kevin howls, Eva let’s him. INT. KEVIN’S BEDROOM - DAY Eva studies Kevin through the bars of his crib. He is sto up still howling and in a rage, though his cheeks are dry his black unnerving eyes seem to directly meet her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Mommy was happy before widdle Kevin came awong, you know that don’t you? And now Mommy wakes up everyday and wishes she were in France. Mommy’s life sucks now, doesn’t Mommy’s life suck? Do you know there are some days that Mommy would rather be dead? Rather than listen to you screech for one more minute, there are some days Mommy would jump off the Brooklyn Bridge. You’ve got daddy snowed but Mommy’s got your number. You’re a little shit aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They understand speech long before they learn to talk. Eva turns to see Franklin standing in the doorway staring her stony faced.  45.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I don’t understand how you can stand there and watch him cry. He pushes past her and picks Kevin up, Kevin instantly quietens.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Franklin ease up, I was only kidding around...I’m blowing off a little steam OK. Siobhan the saint quit, Hear that, Siobhan quit!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Too bad, we'll get someone else. Franklin walks towards the door, rocking Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Look, I‘1l change him...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You can steer clear until you get your mind right, Or jump off a bridge, whichever comes first. He strides off to the kitchen, Eva trails after him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Anyway, what’s this about moving to the suburbs, since when?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Since, i quote, “the little shit” has got mobile... that elevator’s a death trap.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: We can gate off the elevator!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: He needs a yard, somewhere to toss a baseball, fill a pool...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: But i love New York!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You sound like a bumper sticker. You've had twenty years to do what you want and so have I...  46.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well that’s great, I want to go to Africa and you want to go to New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Well you can’t always get what you want.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yeah right. You want a house. You want a yard. You want to coach fucking little league.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Yeah that’s right. And there’s two of us and one of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva lies on her back, eyes open, just about awake. O.S. The sound of the elevator gate sliding open.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: See you tonight. He doesn’t wait for an answer the gate closes and the elevator descends.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (quietly, to herself) Bye. She doesn’t sit up, just lies there, staring at the ceili Something is different, something is missing. Eva sits up in bed. What is it? She gets up and pads into the hall. Silence. She pushes open the door to Kevin’s room. He is sitting u his crib, a ring of discarded toys chucked from it lie on floor. Kevin’s thin pointy face regards Eva stoically. His mouth closed. Silent. Eva looks at him for a moment, opens her mouth to say something but is at a loss for words.  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva stands at the stove fixing coffee, she feels eyes on back and turns. Kevin sits in the centre of the room surrounded by ignore toys staring at her silently.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hungry? No sign of a response, Kevin stares blankly into the air, frozen like a shop dummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shiny red ball rolls slowly across the floorboards and comes to rest between Kevin’s splayed legs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Roll the ball to Mommy Kevin. No response.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin roll the ball to Mommy... He looks at Eva blankly for a moment then turns away, disinterested. INT. DOCTOR FOULKES SURGERY. The doctor holds a finger in front of Kevin’s fathomless eyes, they follow it lazily.

dialogues.speaker: DR FOULKES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ....-None of the tell tale signs...the rocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva sits cross-legged on the floor reading from a lovingl homemade children’s book, Eva has at least found some rel for her creative instinct.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (trying hard) E is for elephant... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EVA (cont'd) large as a house, he’s as big as can be, not small like a mouse... can you say elephant Kevin? El-E- Fant... She looks up; Kevin sits a little way off, his back to he motionless.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin... Kevin, (louder) KEVIN? He does eventually turn round but so laconically it’s har tell if he’s heard her or not.

dialogues.speaker: DR FOULKES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hearing’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red ball rolls across the floor again, straight passe Kevin who seems totally oblivious to it’s existence...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Say “ball” Kevin... Buh...Buh... Ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctors hairy hand inserts a block into a slot puzzle

dialogues.speaker: DR FOULKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can you put the star in the star shaped hole Kevin? Like this? He demonstrates once more then hands the block to Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I mean shouldn’t he be talking?

dialogues.speaker: DR FOULKE
dialogues.text: .. there is no “norm”... you shouldn’t worry too much... They turn their attention back to Kevin, the puzzle in fr of him has been completed flawlessly.

dialogues.speaker: DR FOULKE
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shower curtain slides back, Eva steps out and fumbles a towel. She looks up, Kevin stands in the doorway regard Eva’s naked body with vacant disinterest. She covers hers unsuccessfully with a tiny hand towel, unaccountably embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: When did you learn to walk exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foulke picks up one of Kevin’s arms and lets go, it flops down to his side like a wet noodle.

dialogues.speaker: DR FOULKE
dialogues.text: (bemused) He’s a floppy little boy, isn’t he?... but there’s nothing wrong with him. Kevin stares out of the window, seemingly oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva bends down, smiling broadly she tries once more... wa the ball in the air in front of Kevin before rolling it slowly towards him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Roll it back Kevin... roll it back... And miraculously he does, straight towards her. She catch it and claps her hands with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yay...That’s it, that’s it! She rolls it towards him again. Kevin looks down at the ball resting between his legs the back up at Eva, his face sombre.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Roll it back Kevin!  50. Nothing. INT. LOFT - DAY.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (her kiddy voice becoming more and more forced) OK Kevin, it’s time for our juice! Eva glances at him and sighs, she sets down the cup, he s so under stimulated, she walks to the corner of the room wheels the dusty TV out.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I hate to do this to you but... She picks Kevin up and plonks him down in front of it. A kids animation bursts onto the screen. She turns up the volume. Leaving Kevin to watch she goes back to fetch his juice f the counter. The kids show seems to bombard the room, It’s hyperactive irritating, it pounds through her head and she grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t like dat. Eva looks up at Kevin in total astonishment, the back of head illuminated by the screen. She rushes over, crouching down to face him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What did you say? Kevin’s gaze is still firmly fixed on the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin honey, what don’t you like? He bats his hand against the TV set and Eva marvels.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I don’t like dat. Turn it ov.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Jeez, a kid with good taste.  51. She turns off the TV and grabs an infant picture book fro the floor, hurriedly flicking through the pages.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Look Kevin...Flo-wer...Flow-er. Kevin Look at Mommy, look. Say... Track-tor. Track-tor.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I don’t like dat. She turns him to face her and places both her hands on hi shoulders. Kevin's piercing eyes fix on hers.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin, honey. Can you say Mommy ? He stares at her solemnly. She points to herself.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Mom-mi....Mom-mi. Say Mommi Kevin. His expression remains immutable.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin lies in bed grinning broadly as Eva undresses.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Wow, complete sentences straight off the bat? I’ve read late bloomers can be incredibly bright. They're perfectionist. Don’t want to try it out until they’ve got it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva sits at the table trying to concentrate on some proof from work. Kevin sits behind her on the floor, surrounded a ring of toys. He picks them up one by one, examining ea briefly before flinging them across the room with all his might.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I don like dat... I don like dat... I don’t like dat...  52. Eva throws down the page she’s looking at, she’s driven t distraction... she doesn’t like dat much either. O.S. The elevator arriving.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I don like DA.... With a conspiratorial glance at Eva he falls completely silent.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Damn elevator... hey guys what’s up? He squats down next to Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: And did you learn any new words today, huh? Can you say daddy? Say daddy Kevin. Kevin shakes his head once, his mouth staying resolutely shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EVA is sat on a bench, Kevin facing her in the buggy, eye her moodily. She produces a packet of cookies from her ba bag and holds one out to him.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I don’t like dat.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (Completely exasperated) What do you like, Kevin? With a glazed disinterested expression, slowly turns away INT - BATHROOM- NIGHT. Eva lies against Franklin in the bath. He suddenly slides into sitting position so she has to sit up too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Two months?...He’s only a baby! Franklin steps out of the bath and wraps a towel round hi waist.  53.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: He’s almost three now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: And who’s gonna look after him?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You said you were working too hard, you could take a break... Anyway...I thought you wanted to spend more time with him.

dialogues.speaker: ....WHERE ARE WE
dialogues.text: O.S. A loud honk. The dust clears revealing a placid cow standing staring almost straight at you. EVA hangs onto the side bar in the passenger seat of a La Rover, A YOUNG GUIDE, the driver honks the horn again sev times but the cow just blinks at them. Eventually it shuf off and the jeep pulls away, cruising through the dusty expanse.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN PHONE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kevin....Say hi to Mommy.... C’mon Kevin...don’t you wan’t to talk to Mommy? Oooff...(muffled and two octaves higher after a punch in the nuts from Kevin) Easy tiger.

dialogues.speaker: EVA PHONE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I was thinking...It’s shooting trips for sick millionaires or staying in a mud hut... and the political situation’s fucked. I’m gonna cut my losses and come home.... Franklin? Franklin?...Shit.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva locks eyes with a beautiful African woman who’s sat b the side of the road, suckling her naked child, despite t squalor, it seems like the most natural thing in the worl she looks like a serene Madonna. Her two other small chil make up a game of rolling an old tyre with a stick. Eva smiles at the woman who doesn’t smile back, yet her g seems to penetrate, making Eva uncomfortable. The woman b flies away from the baby’s mouth without dropping her sou eyes. The children chase the tyre screaming and whooping ecstatic delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva runs into the grubby airport, dropping her bags at he feet as she looks up at the departure board, panels flip like cascading dominoes...‘DELAYED’ ‘DELAYED’ ‘DELAYED’. No Air-con, waiting passengers bat away flies, dishevelle the intense heat. Eva covered in a film of sweat, finds the only working vending machine, no water left, only Fanta orange. She ta a slug from the drink. It’s warm and she almost spits it the floor. INT. JFK AIRPORT -DAY. Eva’s feet pound across the airport floor. She crouches down and tears spring to her eyes as she pul Kevin towards her and hugs him tightly, his arms remain a his side and he’s floppy like a rag doll in her embrace.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I missed you so much... Mommy’s never going to go away for this long again. Kevin seems to get floppier still, his head lolls back ov her arm until he’s almost horizontal, she pulls away from and ruffles his hair. Wiping her cheeks, she stands up an hugs Franklin, they kiss passionately. Kevin stamps his foot and begins to make a loud mooing so he tugs at Franklin’s hand. Franklin pulls away from the her.  55.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Look Kevin. Mommy’s got you a present. She pulls a huge wild looking African wooden mask from a carrier bag, waving it in front of him, Kevin is uninterested.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: It might take a while Eva...kids this age... they think you’re never coming back. Kevin hauls Franklin by the leg.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Urghh...urghh Franklin laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Hey I know what you want kid, Cheese doodles! Kevin stamps up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin shoots Eva a crafty orange smile and fists a cheese doodle into her lap.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Mommer farted!..It stinks.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Don’t crumble them all over truck honey.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: C'mon Eva, kids’re messy, loosen up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teenage waitress with a raised brown birthmark on her c scribbles in her order pad.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Garden salad, house dressing on the side.  56.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh nyeh, nyeh nyeh nyeh nyeh nyeh.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: A portion of onion rings.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh, nyeh, nyeh, nyeh, nyeh.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: And a cheese burger.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh nyeh nyeh nyeh.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: (looking like she’d rather kill him) What a cute little boy. The waitress moves to take an order from another table.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: How long has this been going on?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh nyeh nyeh nyeh nyeh nyeh

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: It’s just a phase. He’1ll grow out of it. Eva puts her hand over Franklin's.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Look while I was away. I had a lot of time to think, I don’t feel I'm doing either ‘A Wing and a Prayer’ or motherhood right...

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh, nyeh, nyeh, nyeh...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s time to focus more on Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh, nyeh, nyeh, nyeh...  57.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Work can take a back seat. I’m thinking at least till he’s in first grade.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh, Nyeh, nyeh, nyeh, nyeh. Nyeh. The waitress returns with a tray and sets down their food Kevin scrutinizes her birthmark.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: That lady has poop on her face. Eva looks at the young waitress apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Why don’t you clean your face, It’s poopy?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry I... The waitress smiles but her face turns beet red.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I'll be right back with your dressing. Eva watches as she walks back towards the kitchen with he head bowed, nervously pulling strands of hair over her fa Eva reels back to face Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin, that wasn’t very nice.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh NYEE nyeh nyeh nyeh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Can we not ruin our first afternoon together? Anyway... I have a kind of an announcement to make myself. I bought us a house.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You bought us a house?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh nyeh nyeh nyeh- nyee  58.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You didn’t find one for me to look at? It’s a done deal?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh, NYEH, NYEH..

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin stop it. That’s enough. Let Mommer and Daddy talk.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin quit it!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You’re only making it worse... Look if I didn’t pounce it was going to be snapped up by somebody else. Besides you weren’t interested. I thought you’d be pleased, glad it’s over.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: There’s only so pleased I can get about something that wasn’t my idea in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin I mean it. If you don’t stop Nyeh-nyehing we’re leaving.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Stop it! She leans over the table and raps him on the hand. Kevin almost smiles for a moment, satisfied? Then his lip start quiver and his face crumples up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry ...I’m just tired. I am pleased... I can’t wait to see it.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh nyeh-nyee... nyeh nyeh nyeh....Nyeh nyeh nyeh nyeh nyehnyee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin drives down Palisades Parade. They pass a row of houses, each more revolting and soulless than the next. M

dialogues.speaker: MOCK.
dialogues.text: Eva looks at them with growing concern. Not that one, not that one, please not that one.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So what’s it like?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Wait and see... She gulps. They turn off into a driveway THE RANCH HOUSE looms into view. A modern flat roofed structure of glass sandy brick, it looks like an institution. She hates it on sight... the opposite of everything she’d want in a home. Someone else’s dream home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door swings open, Franklin beams.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me this isn’t dramatic.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m dumbstruck. Kevin looks around glumly, he slackens on Franklin’s hand until he’s a dead weight.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Wanna go explore?  60. Kevin lets go of Franklin’s hand and plods off unenthusiastically, reaching the middle of the immense living room he plops himself down limply on the polished floorboards with a glazed expression. For the first time Eva can relate to him, she feels like doing the same thing. Eva looks round the huge teak panelled space... not a doo sight... everything open-plan, nowhere to hide.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You've got to see the master bedroom, the skylight’s are spectacular.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (Brightly, forced) Skylights!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva stands in the elevator, a last box of odds and ends i her hands, she looks around the empty space ruefully, it’ like saying goodbye to an old friend. She pulls the hand crank and starts to descend, disappear from view. INT. ‘RANCH HOUSE’ NYACK - MOVING IN DAY SQUIRT. A jet of water splashes onto the crotch of a pair jeans.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You peed you pants. Two skinny legs and a skinny body stick out from undernea the huge scary looking African carved wooden mask. Kevin looks like a demented voodoo doll in diapers. He ho a squirt gun in one hand and waves it threateningly at th removal man who he’s just soaked. The guy’s powerless to avoid him, clutching a heavy tea chest.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin, stop squirting the nice removal men, they’re only trying to help. Kevin aims the gun at another removal man’s butt.  61.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I told you to stop it! He drenches the man’s butt.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You peed your pants!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin, I’m not going to tell you again! She chases after him as he thuds past the man.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin if you squirt anybody one more time. I’m taking the gun away! He sprints past the removal guy he’s just soaked so she c get close enough to grab him, then turns back to her wavi the gun in the air, his eyes glistening gleefully through intimidating wooden face.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: NYEH-Nyeh? Nyeh nyeh nyeh NYEE-nyeh nyeh nyeh NYEEEEEEE! He turns and thuds off round the corner, out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin eyes Eva moodily as she puts his confiscated squirt out of reach on top of a cupboard. INT. LIVING ROOM TO KITCHEN —- CONTINUOUS - DAY. Eva struggles into the kitchen with a box of pots and pan Kevin is perched precariously, standing on the second she of an opened cupboard, posing as if waiting to have his picture taken, his hand fumbling for his gun.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hold it right there Mister. Freeze! She waits underneath him, prepared for a fall, he’s too h for her to grab.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Franklin!....quick.  62. Franklin enters and pulls Kevin down but not before he’s snatched his squirt gun back.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kevin’s been very very bad, we’re going to have to take that gun away for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Aw, you’ve earned it haven’t you kiddo. (ruffling his hair) Man that climb took guts, real little monkey aren’t you? Kevin shrugs away from his dad’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (deadpan) I’m the little Monkey. He strides out of the room, gun swinging at his side, wit the nonchalance of an airline hijacker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin is sat at the table, systematically pulling all the stuffing out of a fluffy rabbit through a small hole in i ear. Eva puts a sandwich down in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You must be hungry working so hard? He doesn’t look up.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: No. LATER. O.S. The toilet flushing as Eva emerges from the bathroom She looks at the kitchen table; the sandwich has gone and has Kevin. Huh? So that’s how it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B.C.U. Eva’s hands smooth down a beautiful vintage map of Asia, as she pastes it like wallpaper to the wall and sta back to admire the effect. A pile of old maps, plane tick and postcards sits next to her on the floor. This is gonn look cool.  63. Kevin grunts and she feels his eyes boring into her as he stands watching her leaning slackly in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (as she selects another map ) Everyone needs a room of their own. You know how you have your room. Well this is Mommer’s room...You’1l see, you may want to make your room special some day and I’1l help you if you like.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What do you mean Special?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So it looks like your personality.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What personality?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I think you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I have to put junk on the walls?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Unless you’d rather not.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I'd rather not. Eva sighs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Great, we’ve found one more thing you don’t want to do. Kevin’s face screws up a little, an odd expression follow by a smile... and a stink.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh you haven’t... I only just changed you. Kevin grins with satisfaction.  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin has his head in a kitchen cupboard, fixing child locks to the doors. Eva struggles to fit a beloved old dresser into the next room, the space has no flat walls, nothing fits and the dilapidated dresser looks out of place amongst all the fr clean wood panelling.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Christ doesn’t this place have any corners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva waits in the car with Kevin, looking at a row of phon shop fronts. A huge couple pass by stuffing their faces w burritos.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Look at the roly-pollies Kevin. She only gets a scowl in return. Franklin appears, his arms full of shiny new kitchen equipment.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Have you seen “Ye Olde Sandwich Shoppe”? Must have been built all of six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You’re such a snob sometimes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva helps to carry the new stuff into the house, she pass brimming dumpster. Her old dresser lies amongst the funky pots and pans from the loft, her antiquated food mixer... smiles wistfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S. Kevin can be heard smashing something up in his room Eva puts down a PB and J in front of the door as she pass  65.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Eva passes Kevin’s door again, her arms loaded with laund The plate is empty, a few crumbs remain. Christ it’s like feeding a dog. INT. EVA’S NEW STUDY - DAY BCU A drill whines as it bores into the doorway of the st Eva looks up with satisfaction from her wallpaper pasting (she’s covered about half the room with maps now.) | A carpenter hangs a door, pretty much the only one in the house. He demonstrates the finishing touch, a large smoot functioning bolt. Kevin sits in the corridor watching broodily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva has her back turned to Kevin doing laundry.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I’ve pooped. Eva turns to him with a bright smile which instantly fall from her face. He’s shit all over the kitchen floor the poo clinging and running down his legs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Shit! He shoots her a little grin.

dialogues.speaker: A MOMENT LATER
dialogues.text: A pair of little legs are yanked from the ground, the shi shorts dangle from his foot, then drop to the floor. Eva plonks him in the sink and washes him perfunctorily. seems to be enjoying it, Eva is not.  66. INT. THE KITCHEN —- MORNING Eva stumbles into the kitchen, still half asleep. She sta to fumble around-finding things to fix coffee. Every door clipped with a safety guard nothing opens properly.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Crap. O.S. Franklin and Kevin in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kevin honey? Look at daddy, see how he pee-pees in the pooper- dooper?... Eva rolls her eyes, fat chance... she passes the open doorway, she can see Kevin watching his father.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You could do that too... piddle widdle in the toilet huh? Kevin rolls his eyes lazily toward Eva. An expression fli across his face, Eva can’t be sure but it looks suspiciou like. “What an asshole?”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin is in bed, his hands behind his head. Eva undres

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Jesus why couldn’t he just suck his thumb or something... Eva sighs. She takes her bra off and slips into bed besid him. INT. EVA’S NEW STUDY - DAY Eva pastes the last plane ticket into place on the wall a stands back brushing her hands together with satisfaction maps and memorabilia cover every inch of the walls, even ceiling, it looks fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: All these squiggy squares of paper. They're dumb.  67.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I like them. He stamps his foot.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: They’re dumb. The door bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavily coiffured woman MARY WOOLFORD, stands at the do holding a home baked pie. MARY WOOLFORD. A little something to introduce you into our community. Mary presents the pie whilst having a good nose into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh...how thoughtful. Eva wipes her pasty hands on her overalls, tries to straighten her hair.

dialogues.speaker: MARY WOOLFORD
dialogues.text: (looking Eva up and down) Wow, you look pretty snowed under... we've got a little playgroup going on at my place if your little boy would like to join.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (distractedly) Sure...yeah that sounds fun. MARY WOOLFORD. Every Thursday 2-4pm at my place. The kids really enjoy it and it gives the Mom’s a break. Eva looks up the stairs. It’s quiet, too quiet.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Sorry... (indicating upstairs) I gotta go.  68.

dialogues.speaker: MARY WOOLFORD
dialogues.text: (slightly offended) Sure...I can see you’re busy. Eva closes the door and rolls her eyes, heading up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey kid, when you’re this quiet, you make me nervous.. She pushes the study door open. The expression on her fac changes instantly, she looks at the room in horror. The walls are spidery with red and black ink, the ceiling too, covering all four walls in little circular and zig-z directions. Kevin is standing on the desk, bent over in concentration draining the last of the red ink from the bottle and pour it intently into the barrel of his gun, the ink spills ov onto the already splattered oak desk, his hands are drenc He senses Eva standing watching him but he doesn’t look u

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (quietly) Now...It’s special. Eva is completely awestruck. She snatches the gun from him and throws it on the floor, stamping on it hard until it’s in bits and the ink has ru her pretty yellow pumps. INT. EVA'S CAR, OUTSIDE MARY WOOLFORD’S PLACE - DAY Kid’s pile out of the house. Kevin sullenly gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Did you have fun? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva’s on the phone.  69.

dialogues.speaker: MARY WOOLFORD
dialogues.text: (phone voice) Sorry Eva, but Kindergarten's only a couple of weeks away, we just couldn’t make up the numbers anymore...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (slightly quizzically) Ok... sure, thanks for all your help anyway, it’s been great... OK... bye. She rounds the corner. Kevin stands by the window forcing half a sandwich into his mouth in one go, like a starved animal.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hungry huh? He looks up at her dolefully, spits the half-masticated sandwich out into his hand and mashes it into the window pane, it sticks there. Kevin walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva searches through the annoyingly locked cupboards for something and pulls out Mary’s tacky, ‘home sweet home’ decorated pie dish, she’s forgotten to return it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Crap. EXT. MARY’S HOUSE - DAY Eva approaches the front door carrying the pie dish, she notices a few extra cars parked up outside. She rings the bell and the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey Mary, just thought I’d return this... sorry it’s been so long... She stops, over Mary’s shoulder she can see the lounge fu of mothers and young children, play group is evidently st running, just without Kevin. Mary smiles broadly but her pale neck blotches bright red  70.

dialogues.speaker: MARY WOOLFORD
dialogues.text: Oh... thanks Eva, that’s... great. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well I guess I’1ll see you at “Love and Learn” soon.

dialogues.speaker: MARY WOOLFORD
dialogues.text: Sure, take care... and thanks again. She closes the door. EXT. LOVE AND LEARN KINDERGARTEN - DAY. Eva jumps out of the car and rushes through the brightly colored playground, holding her careworn diaper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS FABRICANT (frumpish, thirties) and Eva stand at the classroom door. Eva holds a freshly-bagged messy diaper a arms length. VIOLETTA, a shy little girl with a bad case eczema hangs onto Miss Fabricant, hiding in her skirts.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FABRICANT
dialogues.text: +..sorry about this Eva...the other children were starting to complain about the smell. VISIBLE OVER HER SHOULDER...A prissy little girl, MUFFET shows the rest of the class a delicate china tea set. She hands cups out to the little group sat around her, includ Kevin. MUFFET. One for you...and one for you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It’s just that this is the third time today, couldn’t you...

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARBRICANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry but it’s the law I could get in a heap of trou.... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MS. FARBRICANT (0.S.) (cont'd) (turning her attention to Violetta whose itching at her scabs)...Don’t scratch honey you know it makes it worse.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know a lot of the other mothers live closer by, it takes me a while to get here.

dialogues.speaker: MS. FARBRICANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Actually, we don’t really have other mothers in this situation. In the background. Kevin holds his tea cup up in mid air almost as if to propose a toast... except that he lets it crash to the floor. Both Eva and Miss Fabricant turn roun moments stunned silence then Muffet starts to shriek as t rest of the kids follow Kevin’s example and let their tea fall and smash, one after the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva drives distractedly, Kevin strapped in the seat next her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That wasn’t very nice Kevin...breaking Muffet’s tea cup.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: She’s got a dumb name.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That doesn’t mean she deserves...

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (lamely) It slipped.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Sure Kevin. How would you like it if you brought something you really care about to school and somebody smashed it up?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Like...  72. She closes her mouth, Kevin smiles triumphantly, she can’ think of a damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: .--in floods of tears, absolutely inconsolable... Franklin pushes away his empty plate, leaning back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (about to brush it off) Well... Eva throws him a look, "We've discussed the ‘united front thing”.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (changing tack) Look Kev... I know tea cups are girly and sissy but don’t break ‘em OK? It’s uncool... Kevin nods dourly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: OK! fancy some frisbee... work on that bank shot?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (uncannily, eerily like a kid from a cereal commercial) Sure Dad! They bounce off together.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Eva watching through the glass doors. Kevin is useless despite practice. Limp, hooked throws th always fall ten feet short of Franklin... who in turn is tireless in running to pick them up. A patience that begs be tested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer, nearly the end of term. Eva waits with the other mothers as the kids come out of school.  73. She notices the unmistakable bulge of a diaper on a few o the kids where there had been none before. Soon, most of kids are gone, Kevin has not materialized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A concerned looking Miss Fabricant is searching the build

dialogues.speaker: MISS FABRICANT
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry Eva, I'm sure he’s around here somewhere... She scurries off to check the bathrooms.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FABRICANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (relieved) Here he is! O.S. A scream. Eva runs to the bathroom door. Kevin has his back to them whispering to VIOLETTA, (the little girl with eczema.) She has her eyes closed, her expression ecstatic... and s is scratching herself to ribbons, blood runs freely from hundreds of scabs she has scratched off her body dripping slowly onto her white ankle socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin bangs a glass down on the counter and pours hims a generous scotch. Eva sits at one end of their new, whit sofa.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: He’s not her minder Eva, he’s a kid.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: He could have called someone, couldn’t he? Before it went too far.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: For Christsakes how’s he supposed to recognize what ‘too far’ is, when all she’s doing is scratching! None of which explains why you let him squish around the house, all afternoon from the looks of him, plastered in shit... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANKLIN (cont'd) Does it occur to you that if this little scene was all that terrible, then he might be a little traumatized himself.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: He wasn’t traumatized, he was smug.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?... He moves to sit down next to her but almost lands on a hu smear of shit streaked down the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Shit. He jumps up and plops himself down at the far end, his ha to his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Look I’m getting pretty sick of this... and not because of Kevin. Silence. Eva and Franklin sit at opposite ends of the sof no eye contact. The shit-smear drawing a dividing line between them. INT. KEVIN’S PLAYROOM, SUMMER - DAY Kevin is slumped on the floor as Eva, knelt in front of h opens the page of a book.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: OK, Lets work on our numbers!

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well you remember yesterday, Mommer paid the bills? You have to be able to add and subtract to pay bills.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You used a calculator.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well you have to know arithmetic to be sure the calculator is right.  75.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Why would you use it at all if it doesn’t always work.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It always works.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: So you don’t need arithmetic.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (flustered) To use a calculator, you still have to know what a five looks like, alright?...Now lets practise our counting. What comes after three.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What comes after nine.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Fifty three. Kevin stares at Eva in the eye lifelessly and drones in a fast forward monotone.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Onetwothreefourfivesixseveneightnin eteneleventwelve... He counts up to fifty, hardly pausing for breath.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Now can we quit? Eva looks stunned, she feels foolish. She sits down besid him and scrawls a bunch of numbers on a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: There! Add that up then! And multiply it by twenty five while you’re at it, since you think you’re so smart! She goes to hand him the paper. Smells something.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You did not.  76. He looks at her, smiling. A FEW MINUTES LATER; On the changing table. Eva removes the stinky diaper. She somewhat gruffly lifts his ankles. Sets out the fresh one under his butt. Her eye catches on his. She studies him. seems to be enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Are you having a laugh out of this? Are you? He doesn’t answer. She finishes taping the diaper sides, yanks up his pants, putting him on the floor and turning wipe her hands. O.S. A squelchy, farting sound. The unmistakable smell. She turns round, Kevin grins up at her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (screaming) How do you do it! You hardly eat anything, where does it come from?! Eva is livid, she grabs him, dragging him towards the changing table, she loses it and before she knows it she’ thrown him towards it. He sails though the air as if in slow motion and lands wi dull thud against the edge of the stainless steel table. His head at a quizzical tilt, he looks at her as if he is finally interested in something. Kevin’s arm is splayed at an odd angle. Eva looks terrifi He does not cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva, Kevin and DR GOLDBLATT walk down the long corridor. Kevin has a haughty expression on his face, he bravely ho his arm, a towel wrapped around it. Eva has her hand on h shoulder but he shrugs it off. They stop in front of the orthopedic surgeon’s examining room. Eva is about to walk in with them. Kevin abruptly t to her.  77.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I can see the doctor by myself.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Don’t you want me to keep you company honey... in case it hurts?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You can wait out there.

dialogues.speaker: DR GOLDBLATT
dialogues.text: That’s quite a little man you’ve got there Eva...Sounds like you got your orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva. A guilt sign is practically lit up over her head. She glances at the floor, terrified to make eye contact w anyone.

dialogues.speaker: HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: Eva sits in the same position, waiting. She holds a tissu that she’s torn to tatters. Suddenly, Doctor Goldblatt and Kevin - in a freshly minte cast, emerge. Eva swallows hard, and desperately tries to read their faces before talking.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GOLDBLATT
dialogues.text: Well. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DR. GOLDBLATT
dialogues.text: I’ve got to tell you this, Eva... Eva blanches. (beat; smiles) This is one brave young man you have here.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. She places her hand delicately on the doctors arm.  78.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (gushing) Thank you, thank you so much Dr Goldblatt. INT. EVA’S CAR - DAY

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (in bits) What Mommer did was very, very wrong. And she’s so, so sorry. Kevin sits up front, he says nothing, his expression aloo the fingers of his plastered right arm tucked Napoleonica into his shirt. INT. LIVING ROOM. Eva holds the front door open as Kevin walks in. Kevin heads straight for the kitchen, Eva meekly follows. Franklin has his back turned, slathering some peanut butt onto a cracker, he turns to face them stuffing it into hi mouth.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Jesus, Kev!. He swallows hard without chewing. He brushes the crumbs from his hands hastily and plunges his knees before Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I broke my arm.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I can see that. How’d that happen? Eva looks flushed and woozy... about to confess.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I fell. Eva stares at Kevin in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Where'd you fall?  79.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I had poopy pants. Mommer went to get more wipes. I fell off the changing table onto my tonka truck. Mommer took me to doctor Goldbutt.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Gosh...that must have hurt!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: The orthopedist says it was pretty clean and should mend well. Kevin and Eva look at each other as if sealing the pact.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Are you going to let me sign your cast?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Sure Dad! But first I got to go to the bathroom. He saunters off with his free hand swinging. Eva looks round her

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (quietly) Did I just hear right?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Guess so. exhausted, close to tears. Franklin puts his arm shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Man, that must have given you a scare.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It was all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: No mother can watch their kid every second. She squirms.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yes... but I should have... Franklin raises his forefinger.  80.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Sh-sh! A delicate trickling emerges from the hall bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (whispering) What do you think did the trick, just the shock...or do you think he’s scared of landing back on that changing table? Eva shrugs... Jesus. EXT. FRIENDLY’S RESTAURANT - DAY Kevin stuffs his mouth with a giant banana split sundae. whittles it down in workman-like fashion. Across from him, Eva sits contritely.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: How is it? Kevin nods without looking up. He keeps eating. INT. EVA’S CAR - DAY

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Do you mind if we stop off at the store honey?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I wanna go home.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (swallowing) Home it is then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva tentatively knocks on Kevin’s door.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Not yet! She waits outside for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva enters the room, Kevin is sat on top of his bed. He i dressed awkwardly. One arm in the sleeve of his pyjama to the other underneath it. She kisses Kevin's forehead, he wipes it off.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I love you, kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nyeh NYEE nyeh, nyeh-nyeeeeh! INT. EVA AND FRANKLIN'S BEDROOM - SUMMER AFTERNOON. Eva wanders round the room on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: And how about JAPWAP? we’re gonna need... oh it’s already done...Oh great.. and the updates for europe? Really? That’s fantastic... Eva’s face doesn’t look so fantastic, she passes a framed photo, her favorite, showing a much younger, fresher and enthusiastic Eva on a trip to Holland, she grimaces at it

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: ...well I guess that’s it for now, don’t hesitate to call if you need anything...thanks Sally, bye. She hangs up looking a little lost, surplus to requiremen She looks down at the yard outside. Franklin whoops as Kevin, his arm now out of the cast, la throws the ball into his mitt. Eva’s face reflected in the glass, she presses her hand against the pane. INT. EVA’S CAR, AFTER SCHOOL RUN - DAY Eva, bored, stuck in a row of yummy mommies in their peop carriers and SUV’s. Kevin equally bored, strapped in the back. O.S. Construction noise. She glances out the window.  82.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Jesus..just what we need... another Pottery Barn. She yawns and flicks on the C.D. player. Elgar swims out she closes her eyes for a minute savoring the peace in th music.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I don’t like that, turn it off. Eva sighs and flicks the music off, resignedly. A long boring silence, interspersed with beeping horns an construction.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (brightly, forced) What shall we do when we get home? No response. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Shall we read a book?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What if the book is boring.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Then we'll find a different one.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What if they’re all boring.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s possible Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I think it’s possible.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: When you grow up you’1l need a job and then you’1ll have to be able to read and write really well or no one will want to hire you.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Dad doesn’t write. He drives around and takes pictures.  83.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: There are other jobs.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What if I don’t want a job?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Then you’d have to go on welfare. The government would give you just a little money but not enough to do anything fun.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What if I don’t want to do anything?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I bet you will.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I think I want to go on welfare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) You tell your kid it’s not funny! O.S. Muffled heated voices. Eva listens from the study...she walks to the landing, peering downstairs. Franklin holds the door open to ROGER CORLEY, flushed and sweating, slightly ridiculous in his tight shorts and expensive cycling shoes that leave him pigeon toed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Rog... maybe Trent was fooling around with the release himself and doesn’t wanna take the rap. Doesn’t mean my kid has to.

dialogues.speaker: OK
dialogues.text: The front door closing, hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin hangs in the door frame.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: What a dick...  84.
