dialogues.text: Well they ran out of water babies...before he know it Lenny had pitched a stone when a car was coming. Kevin said he immediately told Lenny not to do that since somebody could get hurt.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yeah, that sure sounds like Kevin. Franklin sighs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Jesus Eva...It was spectacularly dumb, he admits that. Anyway they ran, didn’t get very far since he realized running was crazy so he grabbed Lenny’s jacket to put the brakes on...and here’s the thing, it seems our friend Lenny Pugh already has something on his record so Kevin took the rap. I have to say I felt kind of dumb for laying into him like that...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You apologized?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Sure, any parents got to admit when they make a mistake. Eva looks dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva emerges from her study, she hears muffled voices comi from Kevin’s room, she stops, listens.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Like you were so smooth dude, I thought that fat fuck was going to kick the shit out of you because you were like driving him insane. “Sir I really must protest, sir.”  106.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, well lucky for you I got Mr. Plastic off my back but you should have heard the scene in here Pugh, fucking nauseating, I though I'd burst into tears before a commercial break from our sponsors. Lenny sniggers.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m serious pal... this one’s gonna cost you. Cause your low rent stunt could do my reputation some serious damage. I got standards, I saved your ass this time but don’t expect a sequel, like ass save II. Rock's over an overpass. It’s fucking trite man, it’s got no class at all. It’s fucking trite. Eva hurries off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva drives home from work along Nyack high street. She pa a huge Barnes and Noble with wide, plate glass windows. S glimpses someone, who else could it be dressed in that outfit? Standing in the travel section in front of a shel full of AWAP guides. O.S. The honk of a car horn. Eva swerves momentarily as she redirects her attention to traffic. She shakes her head, incredulous, her eyes wide. grin of pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva enters, Kevin is slouched against the kitchen unit.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey, didn’t I see you in the bookstore tonight?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Nuh-uh. Eva has her back to him at the sink, a private grin.  107.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Funny... could’ve sworn... Kevin starts to slope off.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: By the way...I’d like to ask you out on a date. He eyes her mistrustfully.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Just to do something together...For fun.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Like do what? Eva shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Maybe a little Christmas shopping, take you to dinner? She pauses, unsure for a moment, then with a wry smile.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Play a round or two of miniature golf? He cracks a sour half smile... she’s secured her date. INT. LIVING ROOM - DAY, THE DATE. Eva waits for Kevin. Franklin sits watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What are you and Celie gonna get up too?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Gosh, gonna have to come up with something to do that doesn’t terrify her, guess that rules out vacuuming.  108. INT. EVA’S CAR - DAY Kevin sits in silence as Eva pulls into the funky little course. It’s a freezing overcast day and Kevin sports his tiny white T. It starts to rain.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you wear a coat?... You just can’t get uncomfortable enough can you? Kevin grins.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Uncomfortable? With my own Mother?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MINIATURE GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Kevin poses with his club like a dapper gentleman, still silent but with a ‘now what?’ look.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well...you won. INT. EVA’S LUNA - OUTSIDE THE MALL - DAY Eva slows at a pedestrian crossing. A huge family waddle across the road all stuffing their faces.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Whenever I see fat people they’re eating...don’t give me that slow metabolism crap. “It’s my glands”...It’s food. Their fat because they eat the wrong food...too much of it and all the time. Silence, she drives on into the lot.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You know you can be kinda harsh sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You're one to talk.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I am. Wonder where I got it?  109. INT. MALL -DAY. Cheesy Christmas music is piped through the store as Eva examines a little scooter. Kevin looking thoroughly bored

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You know a couple of years ago, you give a kid some geeky scooter for Christmas and he‘d have balled his eyes out. Eva lunges at the chance to be collegial.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You’re right...that’s one of the things that’s wrong with this country. It’s so faddish. Still, I wouldn’t want Celia to feel left out.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Mumsy, get real Ciel would be scared shitless. You'd have to hold her little hand everywhere she went or you’d have to carry her scooter and all. EXT. MALL -DAY. They exit the mall without any shopping bags and head tow the car park. INT. BEDROOM - EARLY EVENING. Eva stands in front of the mirror, she dabs a little Opiu behind her ears and puts her earrings in. She takes a loo herself, she looks good. INT. KITCHEN - EARLY EVENING. Celia has tinsel weaved in her hair, helping Franklin arr fish sticks on a tray. Eva bustles in dressed in her hot pink silk dress.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Can you help me fasten this. Franklin turns round.  110.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Wow, you’re not looking very maternal.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I wanted to create a sense of occasion...Anyway I thought you liked this dress. Franklin eyes the slit in the dress, which is cut up the thigh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You don’t want to make him uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m making someone uneasy, obviously. She leaves the room. INT. KITCHEN - EARLY EVENING. Eva enters, Kevin is standing at the sink with his back t her. She looks touched to see that instead of clothing designed for an eight year old, he’s made an effort, lush black slacks and a billowing white fencing shirt. She’s smiles, about to compliment him when he turns aroun gnawing chunks from the half-devoured carcass of a cold chicken. Eva turns white.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m about to take you to dinner. Kevin wipes the grease off the corner of his smirking mou

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I was hungry. You Know....Growing boy.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Put that away right now and get your coat! Eva turns angrily away from him and storms out of the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin shakes his head to the waiter who shrugs and turns Eva, she’s quietly furious.  111.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I'll have the crab salad, steak medium rare and a bottle of Merlot. She snaps the menu shut.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh...and bannoffee pie for desert, thanks. LATER; Eva is eating as Kevin rips a bread roll apart, squeezing into tiny balls. She frowns and takes a deep slug of wine

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So...How’s school going?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: It’s going...You want my course schedule? Eva tries hard not to get annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What about your, ah teachers? Are any of them, you know especially...

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: And what bands are you listening to these days? Next you can wheedle about whether there isn’t some cute little cunt in the front row that’s got me itchy. That way you can segue into how it’s all up to me of course but before balling the chick in the hallway. I might decide to wait until I’m ready...Right around dessert you can ask about drugs. Careful like, Cause you don’t want to scare me into, like, lying my head off, so you have to say how you experimented. Finally once you've sucked up that whole bottle you can go gooey eyed and say how great it is to spend quality time together and you can put an arm around my shoulder and give it a little squeeze. Eva quickly pushes her plate aside, abandoning the food s over ordered.  112.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Alright, Mr. Snide, what do you want to talk about?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: This was your idea. I never said I wanted to talk about a fucking thing. They sit in silence for a long moment. Eva takes another gulp of her wine. Kevin pulls a complimentary crayon from rustic jar in the middle of the table. He idly scribbles the paper table cloth.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: OK, I’ve got a topic. You’re always griping about this country and wishing you were in Malaysia or something. What’s your beef about it?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: OK...since you asked. Eva sits back folding her arms.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: American's are trusting to a fault, innocent in a way that makes them stupid. They are fat, inarticulate and ignorant. They are demanding, impetuous and spoiled. They’re self righteous and superior about their precious democracy and condescending to other nationalities because they think they've got it right, never mind that half the adult population doesn’t vote. Worst of all they have no idea that the rest of the world can’t stand them. All the while Kevin’s eyes have been downcast, still scribbling.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Wow...that’s a whole lot of adjectives. Let’s see. He looks at his markings on the table cloth, ticking off list.  113.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Spoiled? Well, You’re rich and can get pretty much anything you want right. Mmmm... Impetuous, well that’s a pretty good description of that speech you gave right now. Inarticulate....Lemme see. Seems to me I’m sitting across from the lady who goes on these long rants about reality TV when she’s never watched a single show. And that... one of you’re favorite words, Mumsy....is ‘ignorant’ ‘Trusting’ with no idea other people can’t stand them. He underscores that on his list.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Well far as I can tell about the only thing that keeps you and the other dumb ass Americans from being peas in a pod is that you’re not fat and just because you’re skinny, you act self righteous, condescending and superior. Maybe I’d rather have a big cow of a mother who at least didn’t think she was better than everybody else in the fucking country. Eva sits in stunned silence, the waiter passes and she quickly signals for the check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin’s door opens a crack. Eva peers in. No posters, no smelly socks, the bed made with boot camp precision, the shelves virtually empty apart from the cop Robin Hood and a couple of school books. She has a quick guilty snoop around but there’s not much find, a stack of floppies sit next to the computer and sh shuffles through them, weird names, Nostromo... D4-x... S picks one out at random, puts the rest back and slips out the room.  114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva inserts the floppy into her disk drive and starts to download the files.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mommee...Mommee, can you help me? Eva tuts and goes off to find Celia. A MOMENT LATER, Eva returns. The computer has switched it off, she frowns, that’s never happened before. She restarts it but the screen just fills up with weird numbers and error messages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eva bustles through the office doors, she’s struck by odd silence in the office, people at their desks with dar expressions on their faces others hanging round gossiping the water cooler.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Why is nobody working?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: They can’t... every single computer’s gone down... the tech guys are looking into it. Eva blanches... shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva sits at her desk watching the rest of the staff still hanging around aimlessly through the glass partition. John enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Bad news I’m afraid, virus, a nasty one... must have got in through somebody’s E-mail... gonna set us back weeks... plus it looks like we've sent it on to everyone on our mailing list... wont have won any friends there.... Eva raises her eyes to the heavens.  115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva knocks tentatively on Kevin’s door, holding the flopp disk. No answer, she pushes it open.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (tapping the disk) I wanted to ask you, What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You didn’t load it in, did you? Eva looks at him guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Of course not...well only once.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: It only takes once.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Why do you have it?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I keep a collection.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Isn‘t that a peculiar thing to collect?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I don’t like stamps.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What’s the point of it?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: There is no point...that’s the point. Eva turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Mom? Eva turns back to face him.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Your computer’s fucked isn’t it?  116.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (ruefully) Yes it’s fucked. I guess I deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You know if there’s anyone you don’t like and you got their e-mail address, just let me know. Eva laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: OK, I’1ll be sure to do that, though some days the people I don’t like come to quite a list.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (jokily) Better warn them, you've got friends in low places. INT. LOUNGE, CHRISTMAS DAY —- MORNING The massive lounge is decked out with tinsel and a huge t Celia sits on the floor unwrapping a present, a large gla cage with a tiny, furry occupant. She’s ecstatic.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA
dialogues.text: (running to eva) Oh mommy, I love it, I love it! She flings her arms round Eva’s neck, smothering her with kisses.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA
dialogues.text: Thankyouthankyouthankyou... Franklin and Kevin sit on the opposite couch exchanging a ‘girls huh?’ smirk. Kevin unwraps his present, a gleaming cross bow.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: It’s a Series 7, the guy in the shop said it’s the best around... Kevin holds the bow up to his eye expertly, looking down barrel, checking it’s straight lines.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Gee dad, it’s perfect. I’m gonna go practice...  117. He stalks out of the room, Eva watches him go uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva lies against Franklin on a couch, bitching about the politicians on TV. Celia wanders round the room, poking i corners, looking under the table.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey Celia, come on now, time for bed...

dialogues.speaker: CELIA
dialogues.text: (O.S. from under the table) Just a bit longer mommy... INT. HALLWAY - CELIA’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS Eva carries a quietly worried looking Celia in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Right let’s put you to bed... want to say good night to Snuffles?

dialogues.speaker: CELIA
dialogues.text: (quietly her face buried in Eva’s neck) He’s hiding. Eva sets Celia down and looks at the cage.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I can’t see him anywhere... Celia’s face crumples.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA
dialogues.text: It’s my fault, I thought I closed the door... Kevin says I’m stupid and he’s right... stupid, stupid stupid! She bangs her fist against her head, harder and harder. E scared, has to pull her hand away.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Don’t worry honey... I’m sure we'll find him... She doesn’t look so sure.  118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva’s ass poked in the air as she searches the back of a cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Snuffles... Snuffles? Franklin struggles out from behind the fridge, covered in dust and crap.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Face it Eva... he’s gone to the big pet store in the sky...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh don’t say that... Eva looks pained.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Dearly beloved... we are gathered here today...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (whacking him) Stop it! But she can’t help it, they both burst out in giggles, rolling together on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva stands at the sink, Celia sits behind her, drawing at kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: .--and so Snuffles went to play in the garden and he’s made lots of new animal friends... Eva pulls the plug, the water sluggishly refuses to drain away. It finally disappears with a gurgle. Eva wrinkles h nose.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Phew... She reaches up to a high, child-locked cupboard and pulls a bottle of Liquid Plummr, she pours a healthy glug down sink.  119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva’s car squeals to a halt, she leaps out looking pale a desperate. She runs up the steps into the hospital buildi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same hospital corridor where Eva waited for Kevin wit his broken arm. The same green plastic chairs. Eva and Franklin sit in a heavy silence, clutching each others hand tightly. A coffee with a crinkled skin sits s on the table. A surgeon approaches with a sombre expression. Eva and Franklin stand up.

dialogues.speaker: SURGEON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, we really tried but there was too much damage, I'm afraid we couldn’t save the eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engine’s running just to get the heating going, Eva s shivering without a coat. An empty silence. Franklin knocks his head back against the padded headrest stares at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you left it out. Eva looks at him stunned.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I thought about not saying that. She licks her lips and starts to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I didn’t leave it out. Franklin drops his head and sighs.  120.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Eva. Don’t make me do this. You used that ‘Liquid Plumr’ on Saturday, I remember because you went on about how the drain smelled weird or something.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I put it away, back in that high cabinet with the child lock on it. Celia couldn’t even reach that with a chair!...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Then how did it get out?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Good question.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Look, I realize you’re usually very caref...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I remember putting it away Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Do you remember putting on your shoes this morning?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Celie’s in hospital why are we having this conversation?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Because I want you to admit it...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Janis came this morning, maybe...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: She didn’t need it, the drains were already clear...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (she’s got to say it) Fine, why don’t you ask Kevin how the bottle got left out?  121.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Here we go, something goes wrong, you can’t possibly be at fault so you point the finger at your own son.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: He was supposed to be looking after her...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Kevin did everything he should have. He said when she started to scream, he came running and when he found out what it was, he ran water over her face and rinsed her eye as best he could, and then he called an ambulance, even before he called me on the cell...He was a star.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Time...it takes time for that stuff to work. Maybe he did wash it out, but when? When he was finished?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Finished with what? His homework? His archery practice?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Think about it! Eva starts to cry, she presses her finger tips to her eyelids.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She’s seven, not two. Even if I did leave it out.. Why the hell would Celia pour drain cleaner on her own eye. Celia’s afraid of everything. He did it Franklin... oh he did it, he did it! Franklin grabs her arms, looks her in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: That’s enough. I’m ashamed of you... She wrenches herself free, grabs the handle of the door, has to get out. She stumbles towards her car.  122.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Eva! Eva turns round, tears streaming down her face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You know I’m not usually big on shrinks but maybe you should talk to somebody. I think you need help. Eva turns and hurries off to her car; arms clutched aroun her protectively. Franklin’s 4x4 squeals out of the lot behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva drives down a lonely, barely lit highway, the tears h stopped now... she’s just blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin with his head in his hands on the sofa, Eva froz in the armchair across from him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Eva, I can take the years...I just can’t take the days.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So...what do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Last out the school year if we can. Make arrangements over the summer. At least custody is a no brainer.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Is it...You’ve decided?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: (limply) There’s nothing left to decide. It's already happened. Eva notices a shadow cross the hall, Kevin steps into the light. For the first time he stands up straight instead o slouching, he looks older.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: -.-need a drink of water.  123.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Kev...don’t take anything you might have overheard to heart. It’s easy to misunderstand when you hear something out of context.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Why would I not know the context? He takes a single hard swallow and puts the glass back on counter.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I am the context. He turns and leaves the room. INT. LIVING ROOM- NIGHT - WEEKS LATER. Celia is sprawled asleep in the crook of Franklin’s arm o the sofa. On the left side of her face is a flesh colored stick on eye patch. Kevin is sat beside him watching ‘My Granny had my boyfriend's baby’ on the Jerry Springer show. Eva carefully lifts Celia out of Franklin’s arms. INT. CELIA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Celia is awake as Eva slips her into bed.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Celie... when you got hurt? Celia nods solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: CELIA
dialogues.text: (sleepily) I got something in my eye...Kevin helped me wash it out. She turns her head away as if to end the conversation. Eva kisses her and heads towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA
dialogues.text: Mommy !  124. She has covered up her good eye with her hand, then uncov it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: CELIA
dialogues.text: Peek a boo! Eva’s smiles at her but her eyes fill with tears as she closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva is sat on the sofa, she glances up as Kevin strides i the room, the distinct shape of his archery bag draped ov his shoulder, he’s followed by Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Dad Prozac’s not that big a deal Half the kid’s in my school are on some kind of anti-depressant. Eva sighs and rubs her hand through her hair, she looks stressed and guilty.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Something came for you. She nods toward the large Fed Ex package on the floor. Ke sullies towards it and starts to rip it open with Frankli car keys. He pulls a bright yellow kryptonite bike lock out of the along with a spray of Styrofoam beans as Eva eyes him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What’s that for? You don’t even ride your bike.. Franklin walks back into the room holding a beer as Kevin pulls out another identical lock.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Got these for a song off the net... I thought I’d make a bundle selling them at school... Franklin pulls the remote off the coffee table, flopping on the sofa next to Eva and switching on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Good to see someone inherited your business sense huh?  125.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (dryly) Glad to see you’re being so entrepreneurial... INT. BEDROOM - NIGHT. 0.S. Franklin singing tunelessly over the thud of the sho Eva, undresses slowly, she smiles to herself a little sad and gets into bed. She peers over the quilt and watches Franklin through the open door of the en suite. He steps out of the shower and his body flits in and out view, reflected in the mirrors, still fit and athletic. He switches the bathroom light off and gets into bed. Dark, apart from the hypnotic flashing light of the digit clock. RED/BLACK. RED/BLACK. They both lie silent, awake. What more is there to say? He reaches out for her hand and pulls her towards him, kissing her tenderly on the forehead, then more deeply, h moves on top of her. The clock flashes, red black, red black. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door swings open, revealing Celia playing with her Fren toast at the table, behind her Eva in Franklin’s arms exchanging a brief kiss.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gross...  126. INT. KITCHEN - LATER. Kevin picks up his school bag and archery kit swings them over his shoulder and leaves the house, closing the door behind him. O.S. The radio still playing...a new song comes on; Charl ‘I've been to paradise’... The music continues over the following sequence...no other sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey lady, you lady, cursing at your life... It’s a beautiful day as Kevin saunters along the neat manicured tree lined street with an air of confidence. He looks handsome as the wind blows through his hair, his sh billows, he looks every inch the a promising young man... ‘Your a disconted mother and a regimented wife’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pretty girl glances at Kevin as he holds his arm in the in answer to the teacher’s question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “I've no doubt you dream about the things you'll never do The corridors are full of students. Kevin pulls a handful envelopes from his bag and posts them into labelled pigeo holes on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I wish someone had a talked to meet, like I wanna tal you... Kids pile out, laughing and chatting, full of energy. Kev sidles off towards the gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B.C.U. Kevin’s hands as he fixes one of the huge yellow l to the double doors of the gym.  127.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin checks the door again and walks across the empty fl of the gym. A lone basketball sits in a corner he picks i and turns in one movement, shoots a perfect hoop... that was all net. INT. VIEWING GALLERY - HIGH UP IN GYM. “I've run out of places and friendly faces because I need be free”... Kevin's face, handsome and focussed, the best we’ve ever him as he fits arrow after arrow into his crossbow and fi again and again, their whistle and dull thunk just audibl over the music. “I've been to paradise but I've never been to me...” CLOSE UP the lone basketball is pierced by an arrow, nail it to the floor. It deflates slowly with a gentle hiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gym doors burst open, they’re surrounded by police gunman, fireman and paramedics. Kevin is led out calmly i the circus. Helicopters swoop over head, red and blue flashing lights illuminate the dusk sky. Parents teachers and others crowd round in awe, being hel back by more police and barricades. Eva's taut, pale face as she struggles through the crowds Kevin now handcuffed, is escorted to a police car and sat down in the back, the door closed behind him. Suddenly, Eva's desperate face appears at the window as s cups a hand against the glass to cut out the reflection o the flashing lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she stares through the glass.  128. Kevin regards her calmly, placidly searching for somethin her eyes. Whatever it is he doesn’t find it and they stare at each other silently for a moment before the car starts to pull away. One last look from Kevin through the back window, he seem pleased with himself, but he doesn’t smile. O.S. A scream, Eva turns to see Soweto Washington being wheeled out the gym, two arrows sticking out of his muscu thighs. Another gurney is wheeled out, a blanket over the body bu Laura Woolford’s expensive bracelets and hundred dollar Manicure are unmistakable on the one exposed hand. A scre from Mary Woolford as she breaks through the crowd and th herself on top of the body, sobbing uncontrollably. INT. EVA’S CAR - NIGHT Eva drives erratically, constantly hitting redial on her cell.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Franklin you son of a bitch! Tears hot with fury sting her cheeks. INT. WAITING AREA. POLICE STATION - NIGHT. Coffee cup. Plastic cup. Styrofoam coffee cup. O.S. Phones ringing, muted sobbing, distant voices. Kevin name, mispronounced. Eva, exhausted, suddenly aged, a dead look in her eyes, marooned on a black PVC sofa as people rush to and fro, blocking her from view. Her knee shakes involuntarily.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG OFFICER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...-And see the little green and white one, that’s very rare from the days before NYPD blue... A teenage boy sits across from her staring glassily into middle distance without seeming to ever blink, his T-shir speckled with blood.  129. Clutching her stomach Eva stands. The receptionist eyes Eva coldly and nods in the directio the rest room further down the hall. There is a line. RECEPTIONIST. (without making eye contact) You’11 have to wait. Eva meekly sits back down. LATER STILL. Almost alone...a cleaner with a mop and a radio. Eva frozen in the same position on the black sofa.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Would you like to speak to your son? Eva shakes her head, desperate, almost fearful.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then you're free to go Mrs Kachadaurian. She looks up slowly, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: «+--+. I can go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into the lot, everything alien. Dazed, she wanders past her car, failing to recognize it first time down the row. Yet once she finds the car she becomes strangely calm. Sedate. Methodical. Keys. Lights. Seat belt. Windshield wipers on interval, to clear the thin mist. INT. CAR - NIGHT. Eva drives very slowly, breaking on yellow, coming to a legally complete halt at the four way stop though there i traffic. LATER, the car curves up the long drive to the house.  130. Methodically, she turns off the wipers and the lights the locks the car. She picks a leaf off the windscreen, scoops the jump rope the garage floor and hangs it carefully back on it’s hook the wall. INT. KITCHEN, HOUSE - NIGHT. Darkness. O.S. The flick of a light switch. Eva enters the kitchen. The greasy breakfast dishes haven’t been tidied, plates a juice glasses still on the counter, the answer phone blee with a ton of messages. The white muslin curtains of the garden doors drift lazily in the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Franklin?...Celia? Her own voice coming back at her unnerves her, it’s sound small and tinny. She walks through the house, flicking on lights. Nothing. She walks to the deck and looks out on the dark garden. She finds the switch for the floodlights, pausing for wha seems like an age before she flips it. The wide panorama of the garden lit up like a surreal painting. The grass and bushes a vivid green. The blue ni sky twinkling with stars as a backdrop. Celia. Splayed like a discarded rag doll, lies in the grass. A single arrow pins her tiny frame to the ground. Franklin. Stark in the glare of the floods, shafts of arrows throug his neck and upper body, a tragic expression frozen on hi face, profoundly disappointed. A pause.  131. Eva switches off the floodlights. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge woman struggles to reach into the depths of a refrigeration unit and pulls out a five litre tub of ice cream, slapping it on top of her already mountainous shop cart, piled high with groceries. Eva’s cart seems empty by comparison, a half loaf of brea and a bottle of white wine the only contents. She reaches for a carton of eggs and places them on the k seat of the cart, flipping it open to check for breakages they're all whole. O.S. The squeaky wheel of another cart turning into the aisle. Eva looks up. A woman about her age, in an outfit that ma have been fashionable ten years ago and appearing similar run down, is perusing the milk cartons, MARY WOOLFORD. Eva blanches with a look of shocked recognition, pricks o sweat dot her forehead. O.S. The sound of blood singing in her ears. She abandons her cart along with her embroidered Egyptian and wallet and dives into the next aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tin of Campbell’s soup full frame. The rushing noise in Eva’s ears getting louder. She gets herself together and manages to peer around the corner furtively, Mary has gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva unloads her meagre groceries, picks up the egg carton drops it onto the counter with revulsion, it feels sticky The young checkout girl flicks it open.  132.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKOUT GIRL
dialogues.text: Jesus, all twelve. Eva looks around distractedly... Mary had seen her after In fact she can make her out at the other end of the stor watching with an intense mixture of hatred and glee.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (slightly unhinged) I’‘1ll take them as they are.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKOUT GIRL
dialogues.text: But they’re totally...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’1l take them as they are! She hands over her credit card.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKOUT GIRL
dialogues.text: (loudly, as if talking to the room) Khatchadourian, that’s an unusual name. Eva pauses for a moment then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (just as loudly) Yep, I’m the only one in the state. She snatches back her card and the bag containing the glo eggs and strides defiantly out of the store. INT. EVA’S CAR - DAY Eva stops outside her run down, vandalized duplex. A kid with a basketball in his hand stands staring at the still-drying red paint.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Jesus. She lets out a deep sigh; she had forgotten. A man pokes his face out of a neighboring door and shouts something at the kid, who stands stock still for an insta then scoots off. His father ushers him inside and closes door.  133. Eva turns into the driveway. She goes to pick up her groceries from her car, the bag almost bursts open, the g from the eggs all over the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S. An abrasive scrubbing sound. A ladder against the white slatted wall. A watery red liquid rushes down in a sudden wash. Eva's feet appear as she descends. A stained sponge and a scrubbing brush thrown into a buck of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking down the hall, bucket in her hand. She catches a glimpse of her reflection in a mirror... al jumps in fright. A red smear over her nose. Her arms up to the elbow glistening as if she’d just carried out a bloodbath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrubbing her hands in the sink. She can’t budge the thin red line that stubbornly remains under each fingernail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evening sun intensifies the already vivid red light i the kitchen, the strange hue makes the plain omelette sat front of Eva resemble a slab of raw meat. She stares at it, lost in thought, then she takes a bite. Reaching up she pulls a piece of shell from her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva pushes away her empty plate, a neat ring of pieces of eggshell round it’s rim, drains her wine glass and reache for the bottle, a line has been drawn halfway down the la and she pours herself a neat glass careful not to go over half way mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva almost catatonic on the sofa. Channel surfing. The Florida election debate is heating up and seems to be every station... she isn’t remotely interested, settles o the Montel Show. O.S. A woman weeping and the audience booing swims in and as Eva dozes off. FADE TO BLACK. ON THE SOUND TRACK...

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They way I see it, the world is divided into the watchers and the watchees....There is more and more of an audience and less and less to see. Eva comes to, her face lit up by the glow of the TV in th darkness...pale and confused, she focuses on the screen w increasing horror.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: People who actually do anything are a goddamned endangered species. You need us! What would you do without me, film a documentary on paint drying? What are all those folks doing.. but watching me. Don’t you think they would’ve changed the channel by now if all I’d done is get an A in Geometry. Eva mouth falls open... ON THE SCREEN; we catch a brief glimpse of Kevin’s hands he tosses and rolls something between them casually while talks.  135. The camera zooms to one corner of the bare cell, a lone photograph taped to the wall, swims into focus. It’s Eva's favorite picture, the one that went missing. Young, smiling and carefree in Amsterdam. The TV switches off abruptly. CUT TO BLACK. O.S. THE BEEP OF THE ALARM CLOCK.

dialogues.speaker: WHAP
dialogues.text: BATTERED ALARM CLOCK, IT’S FACE CRACKED, BADLY REPAIRED W TAPE. IT READS... MONDAY 8TH APRIL 2001.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva’s feet crunch over the remains of the spilt pills, th crumbs clinging to her bare feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva, now dressed for work but still half asleep dodges a viscous pool of paint that has dripped from the porch as heads for her run-down car. INT. TRAVEL AGENT'S - DAY. A cantankerous but indistinguishable voice garbles down t line, Eva holds the phone away from her ear. She picks at something caught in her hair, pulls it out a inspects it, a dried fleck of red paint, she crumbles it the floor. Eva feels someone hovering and glances up, an over-made u women sporting a “My name is Wanda” lapel badge waits by side.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Okay, I’1l call back with the confirmation... thanks... bye.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Hey Eva...  136. She drops a huge pile of papers on Eva’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: .-i need you to go through these bookings for me this afternoon...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Ummm....I can’t...I’m off this afternoon... I did tell you.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: (tight lipped) Oh sure, that’s right. I forgot...well, just as soon as you can then... She drifts off. INT. EVA’S CAR - DAY A long open road. Well outside town the land is flat dust and bare. A huge, low concrete structure crouches on the horizon, surrounded by wire fencing. Eva swallows and straightens her shoulders, preparing herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva pushes a button on the wall outside the entrance, an electric buzzer sounds. She waits. O.S. The clanking of bolts. The door opens and a paunchy guard, (AL, late forties wit smattering of raised brown facial moles) raises a hand.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Hey Eva.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey Al.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: You’re a week early ain’t ya?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I guess you could call it a special occasion...  137. Eva is led through a series of doors and corridors. She's padded down and searched with a metal detector. Eva knows routine and the guards all seem to know her. Eventually she’s shown into a waiting room by Al, the doo closed behind her. She sits in the corner of the drab, empty room. She yawns, picks up a lone, well thumbed copy of the Nati Enquirer, glances disinterestedly, then tosses it back on table and sighs. The door creaks open, an attractive young black woman pok her head timidly into the room. Eva tries to raise a smil for her but she seems anxious to avoid eye contact. She creeps in and takes a seat in the opposite corner, looking close to tears. After fidgeting restlessly for a moments she gets up, bending to pick up the solitary magazine, she glances up at Eva.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Go right ahead, but there’s not much in there... The woman manages a shy half smile and scurries back to h chair. Eva notices her hands are trembling slightly as sh struggles to turn the pages noiselessly. After a few moments she folds up the magazine and puts it down, casting her eyes around the room she notices the vending machine, standing in the corner. She inserts a few coins, types in her selection. A mechan whirring, a packet of M & M,s is pushed forward, it’s jus about to fall into the drawer below when the whirring sto the candy hangs tentatively in the air, it’s jammed - the machine goes silent. This seems too much for her, she rests her forehead again the clear plastic and lets out a low moan. Suddenly, Eva is at her side. She bends down and gives th vending machine a hearty whack with her fist, the M & M’s drop into the drawer and Eva fishes them out, handing the the black woman with a smile.  138.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Works every time, just gotta hit the right spot... The woman smiles shyly, Eva finds herself holding her han their eyes lock; strangely it’s Eva who’s eyes are fillin with tears.

dialogues.speaker: AL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Loretta Greenleaf? The woman looks round.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Take care honey. Another moment then she releases Eva’s hand and leaves wi the guard.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey Al, you still got something on your face... Kevin is led in. Eva notices a change in his demeanor bef he says a word. All that snide condescension and the swag have fallen away. A couple of fresh scratches on his face his knuckles grazed. He’s wearing an orange jumpsuit- it’s odd to see him wear something not only the normal size but too big for him. H looks dwarfed, confused, bereft. His eyes have shed their glaze and tunneled to the back o his head.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You don’t look happy.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Have I ever? His tone is wan.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I’m almost eighteen aren’t I. He rubs his face, something in his manner shows a glimpse his father, Eva winces.  139.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What is it, going to big school make you nervous?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (incredulously) ‘Nervous!’ Do you know anything about those places?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well you did such a good job, tried as a minor, out of your head on prozac.. You'll be out in a couple of years... He shakes his head in dismay.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You know I saw you on TV

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Oh that. He squirms with a tinge of embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: It was a while ago, you know, I was into a... a thing. He looks away from her. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well I’m not sure about the thing but you sounded quite intelligent, now you only have to come up with something to say that isn’t...

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (wryly) Horseshit?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You do know what day it is? Why they let me come and see you on a Monday?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Oh sure. It’s my anniversary.  140.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That’s right... two years, plenty of time to think about it... She leans forward in her chair slightly.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Look me in the eye and tell me why? Kevin can’t look her in the eye, his eyes shutter nervous between the floor and the blank walls.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (glumly) I used to think I knew... Now I’m not so sure. Without thinking, Eva extends her hand across the table a clasps his. Astonishingly he doesn’t pull away.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Listen...I made you something. A - well sort of present. He draws a dark rectangular wooden box about five inches from his pocket, polishes the oiled wood with the wad of toilet paper it’s been wrapped in. Carefully he slides the box across the table keeping two fingers on the top, the workmanship is surprisingly fine. She reaches, but he keeps his fingers on it fast.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Don’t!...I mean whatever you do. Don’t open it. Eva instinctively shrinks back. She flushes, a little shocked, a little horrified.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (in a stinging tone) I see. I thought that was one of your most treasured possessions. Why ever would you give it up?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: It was like she was, sort of, looking at me all the time. It started to get spooky.  141.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She is looking at you. So is your father... every day. Kevin stares at the table, he shoves the box a little fur towards Eva, then removes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Anyway, I thought you might take this and, well maybe you know -

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Bury it. Eva nods gravely and weighted by the enormity of the requ they spend the remaining minutes of the visit in a heavy leaden silence until the guard calls time. Eva rises slowly followed by Kevin. As she moves to hug him goodbye, he clings to her childis as he never had in childhood proper. He mutters something choked into the upturned collar of her coat...’I’m sorry’ She’s not sure if she’s heard him right but she takes the risk.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry too Kevin. I’m sorry too. INT. EVA’S CAR - EARLY EVENING Empty highway, silence fills the car. Eva flicks on the radio. ‘the Remington fuzz away’.... Scrambling channels, news, talk shows, ads.... --.’an oldie but a goodie’ .---Are you lonesome tonight?... Do you miss me tonight? Neon signs reflected in the windscreen...Taco bell, Stapl Wallmart, swim over Eva's face... Does your memory stray to a bright sunny day. A church sign, a hand with a stop watch,’Lord teach me ho wait.’  142. She pulls up outside the duplex. Turns the engine off. Si in the car. Do the chairs in your parlor seem empty and bare? Later, inside. She sits on the couch dressed only in Franklin’s huge anc rock T-shirt. Absentmindedly, she pulls the material to h face.... breathes in. Her purse, half open sits waiting for her on the table, t box visible. A gulp of wine. She looks at the bottle, it’s down to the halfway mark. Fuck it, fills her glass. Do you gaze at your doorstep and picture me there? Eva, fuzzy...puts her hand out to grip the bannister. The is no bannister. A door at the end of the hall the opposite end to Eva's, room we haven’t seen before, a pause, she pushes the door open. Is your heart filled with pain, shall I come back again? A small, cell like bedroom; a neatly made, single bed. No much else, sparse and impersonal. She places the little box on a bare shelf, beside the onl book, ‘ROBIN HOOD’. Tell me dear are you.... She smooths down the bed covers, stands in the doorway fo moment. Lonesome tonight? Eva turns off the light leaving the empty room... waiting FADE TO BLACK. You know someone said that the world's a stage, and each must play a part...  143. Fate had me playing in love with you as my sweet heart... You read your lines so cleverly and never missed a cue... Now the stage is bare and I'm standing there, with emptiness all around... And if you wont come back to me, then they can bring the curtain down...
